item.title: Exploring JDK 21 New Feature: Virtual Threads
item.description: JDK 21, the latest LTS release of OpenJDK, introduces an exciting new feature called Virtual Threads. In this blog post, we will delve into the details of this feature and explore how it enhances the scalability and performance of concurrent applications.

item.title: Tracking SQLite Database Changes in Git
item.description: SQLite stores data in binary. If you run cat mydb.sqlite, you’ll see a bunch of gibberish that doesn’t resemble structured data at all. If you want to track changes and updates to a database using Git, you won’t be able to see full diffs by default.

item.title: Color Grading DJI D-Cinelike Footage in DaVinci Resolve
item.description: This blog post will focus on color grading in DaVinci Resolve. It will introduce DJI’s D-Cinelike, D-Log color profiles, Sony camera S-Log, and explain the differences between these log formats and normal color profiles. The goal is to provide a tutorial for colorists on how to get the most out of log footage when color grading in DaVinci Resolve.

item.title: Vector Databases: Comparison for Semantic Search and Retrieval-Augmented Generation
item.description: In an era where semantic search and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) are redefining our online interactions, the backbone supporting these advancements is often overlooked: vector databases. If you’re diving into applications like large language models, RAG, or any platform leveraging semantic search.

item.title: Comprehensive Guide to Integrating Swagger with Spring
item.description: In the development process, the interface documentation is a crucial part. It not only facilitates developers in viewing and understanding the functionality and parameters of the interfaces but also helps in coordinating the work between the front-end and back-end development, thereby improving development efficiency. This article will introduce how to use Swagger in Spring Boot to automatically generate interface documentation.

item.title: Chart of Ionizing Radiation Doses Absorbed by Individuals
item.description: This is a chart of the ionizing radiation dose a person can absorb from various sources. The unit for absorbed dose is “Sievert” (Sv), and measures the effect a dose of radiation will have on the cells of the body. One sievert (all at once) will make you sick, and too many more will kill you, but we safely absorb small amounts of natural radiation daily.
